docs.lead_paragraph: Troubled by enlarged male breasts, boys are turning to surgery.  Waiting may be wiser.

headline.main: F.D.A. Panel Rejects Drug for Obesity

docs.abstract: Rimonabant, drug once viewed as possible magic bullet against obesity, is rejected by Food and Drug Administration advisory panel because of concerns that it causes neurological and psychiatric problems and increases risk of suicide; FDA is not expected to approve sale of drug in US without additional safety data; vote is blow to Sanofi-Aventis, which sells drug under brand name Acomplia; company says it will continue to work with FDA to address panel's concerns; vote comes on same day that Roche's drug Xenical becomes available without doctor's prescription under band name Alli; drug is being marketed by GlaxoSmithKline, which purchased over-the-counter rights to drug from Roche and won FDA approval this year to sell product directly to consumers (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: A drug once viewed as a possible magic bullet against obesity was rejected yesterday by a federal advisory panel because of worries that it causes neurological and psychiatric problems and increases the risk of suicide. Although the drug, rimonabant, is already marketed in 37 countries, it is now unlikely that the Food and Drug Administration will approve its sale in the United States without additional safety data.
docs.snippet: A drug once viewed as a possible magic bullet against obesity was rejected yesterday by a federal advisory panel because of worries that it causes neurological and psychiatric problems and increases the risk of suicide.     Although the drug,...

headline.main: A Sense of Anxiety A Shirt Won't Cover

docs.abstract: Gynecomastia, enlarged male breasts, occurs most often in adolescent boys who are experiencing hormonal changes, but can also be caused by other factors including obesity; American Society of Plastic Surgeons reports that nearly 14,000 boys age 13 to 19 had cosmetic surgery to reduce breasts in 2006, which is equal to total number of men having breast reduction in 2004; doctors disagree about whether boys should wait until after puberty to have surgery as increase in testosterone often takes care of problem without surgery; some say boys with gynecomastia suffer extreme embarrassment and should be allowed to have surgery to improve body image and self-esteem; drawing; photo (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: ON a recent afternoon, Dr. Michelle Copeland, a plastic surgeon whose offices face the Metropolitan Museum of Art, clicked her computer's mouse as images of young men's torsos flickered across the screen. Unlike the ancient Greek statues of Herakles or the bronze discus throwers in the newly renovated galleries across the street, the young men in Dr. Copeland's digital images were a bit different: Rather than bearing the broad, flat chests of Greek athletes, their pectoral areas assumed a fuller, more feminine shape. The patients were found to have enlarged male breasts, a condition known as gynecomastia. While it is not a new disorder, more men are seeking treatment for it, and new statistics from the American Society of Plastic Surgeons show that the majority are adolescent boys.

keywords.value: Weill Medical College of Cornell University
keywords.name: organizations

headline.main: Cornell Medical School to Get $400 Million for Research Centers

docs.abstract: Group of philanthropists pledges $400 million to build research centers for Weill Medical College of Cornell University to study obesity, diabetes, cancer and Alzheimer's and other diseases of aging (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: A group of philanthropists led by Joan and Sanford I. Weill plans to announce today that it has pledged $400 million to build research centers and to recruit senior scientists for Weill Medical College of Cornell University. The medical school, based in Manhattan, will use the money for research into and treatment of obesity, diabetes, cancer and the diseases of aging, especially Alzheimer's, which carries a special poignancy for Mr. Weill. His mother died of the disease more than 10 years ago.
